subject: Re: The Call of Cthulhu, Quikscript Edition, now in ePub
msgSnippet: https://sourceforge.net/projects/qs-classics no more copy and paste, hooray!
messageBody:
https://sourceforge.net/projects/qs-classics no more copy and paste, hooray!

--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, Nathan Sharfi <bonusfrogs@...> wrote:
>
> Tim Rice did all the real work. All I did was copy and paste what he did (likely introducing unforced errors of my own; I hadn't heard of https://github.com/coolwanglu/pdf2htmlEX yet) and wrote a makefile to call pandoc, which manages to ensure that the goat entrails had a sufficient quantity of chicken blood mixed in them.*
>
> Thanks, though!
>
>  Nathan
>
> * I assert that this is a fair characterization of the process used to tell iTunes that the ePub has its own fonts, and should be used in preference to Seravek or similar. I spent a good day or two scouring the Web looking for a way to do this and only ended up figuring out what should be done after cracking open _Design Is A Job_ and looking at its contents.
>
> On May 9, 2013, at 11:27 AM, oliver langan <oliver@...> wrote:
>
> >
> >
> > This is a thing of beauty. Thank you.
> >
> > oliver
> >
> >
> > On 3 May 2013, at 22:31, Nathan Sharfi <bonusfrogs@...> wrote:
> >> After playing around with Pandoc, I've managed to get it to generate ePub files that work on my iOS 6.1 devices, at the very least. While <https://github.com/adiabatic/qs-literature> is still the repository URL for all this, the internal URL structure has been changed somewhat.
>
